close_symbols: struct MHD_Connection (definition and semantics of its fields: suspended, tls_state, daemon, state, continue_message_write_offset, write_buffer, write_buffer_send_offset, write_buffer_append_offset, rp, rq, keepalive, etc.)
struct MHD_Response (definition and semantics of fields: data, data_size, data_start, total_size, crc, data_iov, mutex, resp sender identifiers such as MHD_resp_sender_sendfile)

Enumerators / macros for connection states (MHD_CONNECTION_INIT, MHD_CONNECTION_REQ_LINE_RECEIVING, ..., MHD_CONNECTION_HEADERS_SENDING, MHD_CONNECTION_NORMAL_BODY_READY, MHD_CONNECTION_FULL_REPLY_SENT, MHD_CONNECTION_CLOSED, MHD_CONNECTION_UPGRADE, etc.)
check_write_done (function) — may change connection->state and therefore the reachability of subsequent code paths in this function
try_ready_normal_body (function) — may change state, unlock/lock mutexes or otherwise have side effects that affect whether later branches execute
MHD_send_data_ (function) — side effects on socket/connection and its return-value semantics (esp. MHD_ERR_AGAIN_), and any modifications it performs to buffers/offsets
MHD_send_hdr_and_body_ (function) — side effects and return semantics (can indicate partial sends and change where body sending resumes)
MHD_send_iovec_ (function) — side effects when sending iovecs and its return semantics
MHD_send_sendfile_ (function) — sendfile path side effects and return semantics (enabled by _MHD_HAVE_SENDFILE)
CONNECTION_CLOSE_ERROR macro and/or connection_close_error (and MHD_connection_close_) — exact behaviour/side effects when closing a connection (state changes, resource release, logging)
MHD_update_last_activity_ (function) — updates daemon/connection activity (a side effect that influences program behaviour/timing)
MHD_DLOG and logging-related symbols (HAVE_MESSAGES, MHD_DLOG) — logging is a side effect; need to know whether these calls remain after removal
MHD_ERR_AGAIN_ (macro/constant) — semantic meaning of this special non-fatal return code used throughout the function

Preprocessor configuration symbols that gate code paths: HTTPS_SUPPORT, UPGRADE_SUPPORT, _MHD_DEBUG_SEND_DATA, HAVE_MESSAGES, MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS, _MHD_HAVE_SENDFILE — to determine which code is actually compiled
MHD_run_tls_handshake_ and TLS-related constants (MHD_TLS_CONN_NO_TLS, MHD_TLS_CONN_CONNECTED, etc.) — TLS handshake branch can early-return; required to know its side effects
rp.props flags and related macros/constants (rp.props.send_reply_body, rp.props.chunked, MHD_CONN_MUST_UPGRADE) — these fields control which send branches execute and thus whether code is removable
str_conn_error_ (function) — used in logging; needed to know logging side effects and potential dependencies
explanation: To decide whether portions of MHD_connection_handle_write are dead code you must know (a) which switch cases and branches can actually be compiled in and exercised at runtime, (b) which calls/branches produce externally visible side effects (I/O, logging, state transitions, connection close, timestamp updates, mutex operations), and (c) which routines mutate connection->state or other shared state that later code relies on. The listed symbols provide the layout and semantics of the in-function data (MHD_Connection, MHD_Response, state enumerators and rp.props flags), the functions/macros that produce side effects or control flow (all MHD_send_*, MHD_run_tls_handshake_, try_ready_normal_body, check_write_done, CONNECTION_CLOSE_ERROR, MHD_update_last_activity_, MHD_DLOG/str_conn_error_), the special return code meaning (MHD_ERR_AGAIN_), and the preprocessor flags that determine whether code is present. With these symbols an analyst (or automated checker) can determine whether removing any statement or branch would change observable behaviour (I/O, state transitions, locking, timing or logs) and so whether it is dead under the MISRA rule.
